concept.title: Storing and Referencing Sensitive Values
concept.shortdesc: For increased security you can keep sensitive configuration values, such as passwords, in files instead of saving them in the configuration file. By default, the expects the email password and keystore file password in separate files.

conbody.p:
Data Collector configuration filestoring passwords and other sensitive valuespasswordsstoring in filesTo store and reference sensitive information:
Create a text file for each configuration value that you want to safeguard.
Include only one configuration value in each file.
You can store any configuration value in a separate file, but do not include more than one configuration value in a file.
Save the file in the same directory as the configuration file: <SDC_installdir>/etc.
In the configuration file, set the relevant value to the appropriate file name. Surround the file name with @ symbols as follows: @<filename>@. For example, if you configure xmail.username as follows, the checks the xmail_username.txt file for the user name:xmail.username=@xmail_username.txt@
